feed.title: NewsTracker: netanyahu
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: Hard-right shift delivers upset election win for Netanyahu
entry.summary: Although Netanyahu must still put together a coalition, his victory all but guarantees that Israel's president will give him the first opportunity to form a government, putting him course to become the longest-serving leader in the country's history.

entry.title: Final polls say Benjamin Netanyahu is on pace to lose Israel's election
entry.summary: With polls showing Netanyahu's natural allies on the right likely to win the most seats overall, he has a clear advantage in piecing together a coalition and may instead be tasked by President Reuven Rivlin with forming a government.

entry.title: Netanyahu receives two-week extension to form government
entry.summary: "We made progress and we are on the way to forming a government, but I need additional time for it to be stable and to reach agreements on important issues that will help us meet all the challenges facing Israel," Netanyahu said during a meeting with President Reuven Rivlin.

entry.title: Israel's Rivlin gives Netanyahu extra 14 days to form govt
entry.summary: "I am giving you another 14 days to put together a government," Rivlin told Netanyahu in remarks broadcast live on Israel's main radio stations after the premier formally requested an extension.

entry.title: Israeli leader gets 2-week extension to form coalition
entry.summary: Israeli President Reuven Rivlin granted Netanyahu the extension Monday.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu gets 2-week extension as he struggles to assemble governing coalition
Despite Victory, Netanyahu Is Struggling To Form Coalition
Netanyahu wins Israel election after sharp shift to the right
entry.summary: In a statement, Likud said Netanyahu intended to form a new government within weeks, with negotiations already underway with the pro-settler Jewish Home party led by Naftali Bennett, as well as with religious groups.

entry.title: Despite victory, Israeli leader struggling to form coalition
entry.summary:
But after weeks of negotiations with potential partners, Netanyahu is finding the task harder than expected and is flirting with the idea of reaching out to his main dovish rivals to form a unity government.

Throughout the heated campaign, Netanyahu ruled out the possibility of joining forces with Isaac Herzog and his center-left Zionist Union and vowed to rule from the right.

Netanyahu looks close to finalizing deals with two ultra-Orthodox parties, Shas and Yahadut Hatorah, who are seeking ministries and parliamentary committees with large budgets catering to their constituents.

But large gaps remain with the two other pieces needed to complete the puzzle, the nationalist Jewish Home and Yisrael Beiteinu parties, both of whom are led by long-time Netanyahu associates who have a tumultuous relationship with the boss.

Tsahi Hanegbi, the deputy foreign minister from Netanyahu's Likud Party, said the prospect of Herzog joining the coalition was only becoming a possibility due to the hard-ball approach of the right-wing parties.

entry.title: News24.com | US, Iran resume nuclear talks after Netanyahu speech
entry.summary: On Tuesday in Washington, Netanyahu told Congress that the agreement taking shape is dangerous and would allow Iran the ability to develop nuclear weapons.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu speaks to Putin, protests Russian plans to sell advanced missiles to Iran
entry.summary: Benjamin Netanyahu's office says he spoke with Vladimir Putin Tuesday to protest Russia's planned delivery of advanced S-300 air defense missile systems to the Islamic Republic.

entry.title: Iran must end 'aggression' for sanctions relief: Netanyahu
entry.summary:
But Netanyahu, whose government has repeatedly denounced the framework agreement as an "historic mistake", said any such move should be linked to other issues.

"To my regret, all of the things I warned about vis-a-vis the framework agreement that was put together in Lausanne are coming true before our eyes," Netanyahu's office quoted him as saying, referring to the Swiss city where the framework deal was agreed.

entry.title: Israel's prime minister says sanctions should remain in place until Iran ends its 'aggression'
entry.summary:
Benjamin Netanyahu has harshly criticized the U.S.-led framework deal with Iran, which offers relief from sanctions in exchange for scaling back its suspect nuclear program.

Netanyahu said Sunday that a better deal would tie the lifting of all sanctions, "to an end of Iran's aggression in the region, its worldwide terrorism and its threats to annihilate Israel."

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu says sanctions should remain on Iran
Iran cannot be trusted, Netanyahu warns
entry.summary: "To my regret, all of the things I warned about vis-a-vis the framework agreement that was put together in Lausanne are coming true before our eyes," Netanyahu said.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu says no Palestinian state if he remains PM
entry.summary:
Netanyahu dissolved his government in December and ordered the new election, two years ahead of schedule, in the belief that he would cruise to a new term.

Kahlon, who broke off from Netanyahu's Likud, is demanding to become finance minister in the next government and has given no indication as to whom he would prefer as prime minister.

He accused both Netanyahu and Herzog of working outside deals with special interest groups and said that only he was tackling the real issues facing the Israeli middle class.

entry.title: Walker says he expects to meet with Netanyahu in Israel
entry.summary: Walker said his goal is to meet with Netanyahu and other members of the Israeli government to get an understanding of the issues facing the Middle East.

entry.title: Walker says he expects to meet with Netanyahu in Israel
entry.summary:
(AP) - Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker says he "absolutely" expects to meet with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu during his first visit to Israel next month.

Walker, a Republican, told The Associated Press in an interview ahead of his departure on a European trade mission that the Netanyahu meeting in mid-May is not yet confirmed, but that it's his "hope and expectation" it will happen.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu to address Congress in speech that has strained ties with Obama
entry.summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu addresses a joint meeting of Congress in the House Chamber on Capitol Hill, March 3, 2015.

entry.title: Netanyahu blasts Iran nuclear deal
entry.summary:
Israel's government reacted angrily to the historic agreement, which aims for a June 30 deadline for a final deal, with Netanyahu demanding that Iranian recognition of the Jewish state's right to exist be written into the agreement.

Ben Rhodes, the US deputy national security adviser for strategic communications, said Netanyahu was wrong because no deal could be reached that involved Iran dismantling its nuclear program.

entry.title: Netanyahu blasts Iran nuclear deal
entry.summary: Relations between Israel and its traditionally staunch US ally are at a low and were hugely damaged when Netanyahu took the unprecedented step of addressing Congress last month to attack the nuclear negotiations with Iran.

entry.title: Netanyahu seeks better deal on Iran; Obama says it is best hope on nuclear issue
entry.summary: Obama, whose relations with Netanyahu have frayed badly over the Iran issue, sought to assure Israelis he understands their concerns.

entry.title: Netanyahu: Nuke deal enables Iran "terror machine"
entry.summary: "[T]hat is: standing firm, ratcheting up the pressure, until you get a better deal," Netanyahu said.

entry.title: Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu once again blasts Iran nuclear deal
entry.summary: "It doesn't roll back Iran's nuclear program," Netanyahu said, one of several US networks he appeared on to slam the deal.

entry.title: Netanyahu once again blasts Iran nuclear deal
entry.summary: When asked if he trusts President Barack Obama, Netanyahu replied: "I trust that the president is doing what he thinks is good for the United States, but I think that we can have a legitimate difference of opinion on this because I think Iran has shown to be completely distrustful."

entry.title: Netanyahu presses U.S. to seek better deal on Iran
entry.summary:
In appearances on U.S. television on Sunday, Netanyahu did not repeat his assertion on Friday that any final agreement should include a commitment by Iran recognizing Israel's right to exist.

Appearing on CNN, Senator Dianne Feinstein, a leading Democratic voice on foreign affairs, said she did not believe the agreement threatened Israel, and had harsh words for Netanyahu.

entry.title: Netanyahu presses U.S. to seek better deal on Iran
entry.summary: Netanyahu said he has spoken with both Democrats and Republicans in Congress - nearly two thirds of House of Representatives members and a similar number in the U.S. Senate - about the Iran nuclear issue.

entry.title: Netanyahu presses U.S. to seek better deal on Iran: CNN
entry.summary: Netanyahu denied he was coordinating with House of Representatives Speaker John Boehner, who visited Israel last week, and with other Republicans to block the Iran deal.

entry.title: Ethnic tensions between Israeli Jews fuel Netanyahu victory
entry.summary: FILE - In this March 17, 2015 file photo, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu Likud party supporters react to exit poll results at the party's election headquarters In Tel Aviv.

entry.title: Ethnic tensions between Israeli Jews fuel Netanyahu victory
entry.summary: Netanyahu, whose hard-line rhetoric taps into Mizrahi disdain for the Arabs who mistreated them in their countries of origin, "speaks not only fluent English, but also fluent Mizrahi," wrote Avi Issacharoff in the Times of Israel website.

entry.title: Ethnic tensions between Israeli Jews fuel Netanyahu victory
entry.summary:
Mizrahi, or Middle Eastern, Jews heavily backed Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's Likud Party, while Ashkenazi, or European, Jews mostly identified with the opposition Zionist Union.

Since Netanyahu's win, the sides have been exchanging insults that have not been heard in public in a generation - with the Mizrahi voters accused of being primitive and Ashkenazi voters viewed as elitist.

They also often argue that Netanyahu's hard-line policies toward the Palestinians prevent a peace agreement that would bring on an economic boom that would benefit Mizrahim.

Yet voting patterns from this month's election indicate that Netanyahu largely owes his re-election to the last-minute mobilization of Likud's Mizrahi supporters.

entry.title: Ethnic tensions between Israeli Jews fuel Netanyahu victory
entry.summary: Many had pledged to turn their back on Likud to protest its economic policies or because of disdain for Netanyahu's lengthy rule and perceived decadent lifestyle.

entry.title: Netanyahu's Allies Blame White House Criticism On Misunderstanding
entry.summary: Netanyahu, leader of the right-wing Likud party, is likely to be given the nod as early as Wednesday to start what could be up to 42 days of negotiations with potential cabinet partners.

entry.title: NO 'RIGHT TO EXIST'? State Dept. rejects call for Iran deal to affirm Israel
entry.summary: To that, Netanyahu said: "The survival of Israel is non-negotiable."

entry.title: FACT CHECK: Did Netanyahu go too far in US speech?
entry.summary:
NETANYAHU: "If Iran's intercontinental ballistic missile program is not part of the deal, and so far, Iran refuses to even put it on the negotiating table, well, Iran could have the means to deliver that nuclear arsenal to the far-reach corners of the Earth, including to every part of the United States."

On the whole, Netanyahu largely adhered to what is known about the nuclear negotiations between world powers and Iran, even if he predicted far direr consequences for the Middle East and the world if a deal is reached this month.

entry.title: Massachusetts delegation divided on Netanyahu speech
entry.summary: Mr Netanyahu is expected to use the speech as part of his effort to derail negotiations between leading nations and Iran over its nuclear program, one of the administration's highest priorities.

entry.title: Israel will not accept Iran nuclear deal, says Binyamin Netanyahu
entry.summary: "This deal would pose a grave danger to the region and to the world and would threaten the very survival of the state of Israel," Netanyahu said.

entry.title: Netanyahu: Israel Cabinet strongly opposes Iran nuclear deal
entry.summary: On Friday, the eve of the Jewish Passover holiday, Netanyahu convened his Cabinet for a special session to discuss the emerging framework, reached after a week of grueling negotiations in Lausanne, Switzerland.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu Says His Cabinet United in 'Strongly Opposing' Proposed Iran Nuclear Deal
Iran nuclear deal threatens Israel's existence, Benjamin Netanyahu tells President Obama
entry.summary: Obama called Netanyahu within hours of the deal being struck, saying it represented significant progress toward a lasting solution that cuts off Iran's path to a nuclear weapon.

entry.title: Obama tells Netanyahu U.S. to 'reassess' policy on Israel, Mideast diplomacy
entry.summary: The harsh U.S. response signaled that relations with Israel, already at their lowest point since Obama took office, could deteriorate further as an end-of-March deadline looms in U.S.-led nuclear diplomacy with Iran that Netanyahu vehemently opposes.

entry.title: Netanyahu: Deal must 'significantly' curb Iran nuke program
entry.summary: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been a leading critic of the nuclear talks, which aim to curb Iran's suspect nuclear program.

entry.title: Netanyahu: Deal must 'significantly' curb Iran nuke program
entry.summary:
Netanyahu has said he believes the deal, which must be finalized in the coming months, will leave too much of Iran's nuclear infrastructure intact.

"Any deal must significantly roll back Iran's nuclear capabilities and stop its terrorism and aggression," Netanyahu said on Twitter, minutes before the announcement from Lausanne.

entry.title: US, Israel have no choice but to work together: Netanyahu
entry.summary: The news that Netanyahu on Tuesday had won an unprecedented fourth term as Israeli prime minister has been met with a cool reception in the White House.

entry.title: With 'no-state' pledge, Netanyahu reignites Palestine debate
entry.summary:
White House spokesman Josh Earnest reaffirmed President Barack Obama's focus on a two-state solution and said that based on Netanyahu's comments, the United States "will evaluate our approach to this situation moving forward".

The question is whether Netanyahu - who shifted sharply to the right in the last days of his campaign, using messages such as the 'no-state' pledge to successfully draw right-wing votes away from ultranationalist parties - really meant what he said.

Netanyahu later qualified his pre-election statement in an interview with the U.S. television network, MSNBC, on Thursday, saying he still seeks a two-state solution but the time may not be right for one just now.

There is no active discussion along those lines, or of a two-state solution, because the last peace talks broke down last April and Netanyahu has said repeatedly that he does not see Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas, who has struck a unity deal with the Islamist group Hamas, as a partner for peace.

But a U.S. official said it was possible the Obama administration would now allow a Security Council resolution on a two-state solution to proceed by withholding its veto, a move that would alarm Netanyahu's government.

For the Palestinians, Netanyahu's intransigence - and his honest acknowledgement that he doesn't want a Palestinian state - may end up bolstering their cause while further isolating Israel internationally, particularly among its chief trading partners, the European Union and United States.

entry.title: Benjamin Netanyahu gives controversial speech to US congress
entry.summary:
Speaking after the address, Mr Obama said Mr Netanyahu had offered no new alternatives to preventing Iran from developing nuclear weapons, and noted that his rhetoric on Iran's nuclear program had been proved wrong in the past.

Observers agreed that Mr Netanyahu had made an effective political speech, deftly articulating his opposition to negotiations with Iran, and that he had severely damaged his relationship with Barack Obama, the leader of his nation's most crucial ally.

Mr Netanyahu, who the Republican House Speaker, John Boehner, had invited to address Congress without notifying the White House - a serious breach of protocol - was interrupted by applause over 40 times.

entry.title: Netanyahu, Boehner hail 'strong' US, Israel ties
News24.com | Netanyahu: Iran deal will allow nuclear breakout
entry.summary: "It appears the deal being formed in Lausanne will leave Iran with underground facilities, the nuclear reactor in Arak and with advanced centrifuges," Netanyahu said at a parliamentary ceremony.

entry.title: Boehner off to Israel; Netanyahu's ties to Obama hit new low
entry.summary: President Barack Obama bristled when Boehner invited Netanyahu to address U.S. lawmakers earlier this month about his fears that an emerging nuclear agreement would pave Iran's path to nuclear weapons.

entry.title: Despite tie, Netanyahu secures shot at 4th term as Israel PM
entry.summary:
Israel's election has yielded a fractured parliament and no clear winner, setting up a horse-trading phase that seems likely to leave Netanyahu in his post and place the country on the brink of confrontation with the world.

The relationship between Obama and Netanyahu has become increasingly strained, particularly after the Israeli leader openly challenged the president's efforts to negotiate a deal on curbing Iran's nuclear program.

entry.title: Netanyahu's shock re-election leaves Israel's pollsters red-faced
entry.summary:
If they did participate, they may also not have been honest about the way they voted and as exit polls close earlier than the real polls, a last-minute surge in Likud votes, in response to a call from Netanyahu, may have been missed, he said.

Still, Degani said he anticipated Netanyahu's win by finding that at least half of wavering voters would choose Likud, adding that some of those respondents viewed themselves as rallying against Zionist Union's strong showing in opinion polls.

entry.title: Netanyahu's Likud surges to stunning Israeli election win
entry.summary:
Netanyahu focused his campaign primarily on security issues, while his opponents instead pledged to address the country's high cost of living and accused the leader of being out of touch with everyday people.

Herzog, who appeared poised only days ago to stage a coup, conceded defeat, saying he called Netanyahu and offered him congratulations.

entry.title: Netanyahu owes win to jitters over Iran-Gulf official
entry.summary: "With Iran emerging again, it was highly expected that Netanyahu would win," said the Gulf Arab official, who declined to be identified due to the sensitivity of the matter.

entry.title: Netanyahu secures resounding victory in Israeli election
entry.summary:
Given the final results, it is all but assured that Israel's largely ceremonial President Reuven Rivlin will task Netanyahu with forming a new government.

"Against all odds, we achieved a great victory for the Likud," Netanyahu told supporters at his election night headquarters, declaring victory even before final results were known.

Netanyahu's return to power for a fourth term likely spells trouble for Mideast peace efforts and could further escalate tensions with the United States.

entry.title: Israeli candidates on last day of campaign before election to determine Netanyahu's future
entry.summary:
Netanyahu, who has governed for the past six years and has long been the most dominant personality in Israeli politics, has watched his standing plummet in recent weeks.

Tuesday's election caps an acrimonious three-month campaign that is widely seen as a referendum on Netanyahu.

The hard-line leader has portrayed himself as the only politician capable of confronting Israel's numerous security challenges, while his opponents have focused on the country's high cost of living and presented Netanyahu as imperious and out of touch with the common man.

As Netanyahu's poll numbers have dropped in recent days, he has appeared increasingly desperate, stepping up his nationalistic rhetoric in a series of interviews to local media to appeal to his core base.

Netanyahu has also complained of an international conspiracy to oust him, funded by wealthy foreigners who dislike him, and on Sunday night, he addressed an outdoor rally before tens of thousands of hard-line supporters in Tel Aviv.

Speaking to the nrg news website, Netanyahu said that turning over captured territory to the Palestinians would clear the way for Islamic extremists to take control and attack Israel.

It was the latest - and clearest - attempt by Netanyahu to disavow his earlier support for Palestinian independence, which he first laid out in a landmark 2009 speech.

entry.title: Disputes emerge as Netanyahu starts work on new Israel govt
entry.summary:
For now, Netanyahu's focus is likely to be squarely on the marathon talks between his right-wing Likud and the five parties endorsing his premiership.

Representatives of the four other parties met with Likud's negotiating team throughout the day, with statements from Netanyahu's party providing no details.

entry.title: Disputes emerge as Netanyahu starts work on new Israel govt
entry.summary: Since the election, Netanyahu has sought to backtrack on his remarks on a Palestinian state, and issued a public apology to the Arab community.

entry.title: Benjamin Netanyahu asked to form Israel's government
entry.summary:
Israeli law does not oblige the president to assign the task of forming the government to the party that won the largest share of votes, in this case Mr Netanyahu's Likud.

Mr Netanyahu said that "Israel's hand remains extended in peace to our Palestinian neighbours" but that security was the basis for hope of a genuine peace.

Referring to relations with the US, Mr Netanyahu said: "We deeply value the alliance with our greatest of friends and will act to preserve it."

Mr Netanyahu will have several weeks to negotiate with potential members of his coalition to reconcile demands over appointments and ideological positions and ensure a stable government.

In addition to the widening gap between the White House and Mr Netanyahu, Israel may be facing pressure from the European Union concerning policies in East Jerusalem.

Accepting Mr Rivlin's appointment to form the next coalition, Mr Netanyahu thanked Israeli citizens for their trust, pledged to "mend the rifts" between different segments of society and called for the nation to put election divisions behind it.

entry.title: Netanyahu makes last attempt for rightwing vote at Tel Aviv rally
entry.summary: Kahlon, a former member of Netanyahu's Likud party whose newly formed centrist party could be a deciding factor in who becomes prime minister, dismissed the offer as a pre-election stunt.

entry.title: Netanyahu legacy on the line in Israeli vote
entry.summary:
The son of a Jewish historian, and scarred by the loss of his brother in a 1976 Israeli commando raid on a hijacked airline in Uganda, Netanyahu often portrays himself - and his country - in historical terms.

It was vintage Netanyahu, delivered in flawless, American-accented English - developed during a childhood in Philadelphia and later as a university student at MIT - and with the gifted oratorical flourish that has made him prominent on the international stage.

The speech, delivered over White House objections, has worsened an already troubled relationship with President Barack Obama, boding poorly for the final two years of Obama's term if Netanyahu is re-elected.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu Takes Conciliatory Tone
entry.summary: Although his party does not control a majority, party leaders controlling a total of 67 seats recommended that Netanyahu lead the next government for what would be his third consecutive term.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu takes conciliatory tone
entry.summary: Netanyahu spoke at a ceremony where the country's president, Reuven Rivlin, officially handed him the task of forming the next government.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu takes conciliatory tone
entry.summary: Netanyahu's comments appeared to be aimed at repairing the damage caused by comments he made in the final days of the campaign that strained relations with the U.S. and drew accusations of racism from the country's Arab minority.

entry.title: Netanyahu gets go-ahead to form Israel's next government
entry.summary:
President Reuven Rivlin had some uncharacteristic criticism of Netanyahu as he went through the formality of handing him a mandate to establish a new government, having verified with party leaders that a majority supported him.

In addition, centrist Kulanu, with 10 seats, ultra-Orthodox Shas, with seven, and United Torah Judaism, with six, have also backed Netanyahu, whose Likud has 30 legislators of its own.

Netanyahu's pre-election promise that there would be no Palestinian state on his watch and his comments about Arab voters further aggravated his testy relationship with U.S. President Barack Obama, who has dismissed his subsequent attempts to backtrack.

entry.title: Netanyahu to form next government after US spat
entry.summary:
In a bid to ramp up votes, Netanyahu veered sharply to the right, vowing there would be no Palestinian state on his watch, promising to increase settlement construction and warning that Arab Israeli voters were going "in droves" to the polls.

"We believe that two states is the best path forward for Israel's security, for Palestinian aspirations and for regional stability... Prime Minister Netanyahu has a different approach."

entry.title: Netanyahu, Putin on same 'businesslike' level with Obama
entry.summary: So at least with Netanyahu, Obama kept the relationship description at "very businesslike."

entry.title: Obama describes relations with Netanyahu as 'businesslike,' same term used for Putin
entry.summary:
That appears to put Netanyahu on a par with Russian President Vladimir Putin.

Relations have cooled further since Netanyahu has been vocal in his criticism of the nuclear talks with Iran and since he declared that a Palestinian state would not be created as long as he was prime minister.

entry.title: Netanyahu, Putin on same 'businesslike' level with Obama
Obama: Prospect for Palestinian state still unclear despite Netanyahu's clarifications
entry.summary: Obama noted a tendency in reporting to frame the current dispute as a personal issue between Netanyahu and Obama.

entry.title: Obama: Netanyahu Statements Don't Clarify Two-State Solution
Arab-Israeli leaders reject Netanyahu's apology for offending Arabs
entry.summary: In the Arab village of Abu Ghosh, a symbol of coexistence with its famous hummus restaurants packed with Jewish visitors, Arab residents were not impressed by Netanyahu's kind words.

entry.title: Arab-Israeli Political Leaders Reject Netanyahu's Apology
entry.summary: Emilie Moatti, a spokeswoman for the Joint List, said the Arab dignitaries who gathered at Netanyahu's home where the apology was filmed were all Likud supporters, with no Joint List representatives invited.

entry.title: Arab-Israeli leaders reject Netanyahu's apology for offending Arabs in election-day comment
entry.summary:
Arab politicians said his election victory was illegitimate, claiming Netanyahu won the vote by pandering to anti-Arab fears.

"We call on Netanyahu to return the mandate he received on the basis of incitement and fear-mongering," the Joint List said in a statement.

entry.title: Arab-Israeli political leaders reject Netanyahu's apology
entry.summary: Arab-Israeli politician Ahmed Tibi told Israel Radio Tuesday that Netanyahu's attempt to defuse the dispute was "not an honest apology."

entry.title: Majority winner Netanyahu apologises to Arab Israelis
entry.summary:
"His excuses are not acceptable because not only does Benjamin Netanyahu plan to bring in racist legislation but his words challenged the very right of Arab Israelis to vote for the Knesset," Israel's parliament, he said on television.

Netanyahu is expected to be formally handed the task of building a coalition government on Wednesday after securing the backing of a solid majority of MPs in the 120-seat Knesset.

Backing for Netanyahu to stay in the post came during two days of talks between President Reuven Rivlin and representatives of the 10 parties elected to parliament who told him whom they would recommend as prime minister.

entry.title: Majority winner Netanyahu apologises to Arab Israelis
entry.summary: Netanyahu made a last-minute call to his supporters to vote last Tuesday in an attempt to counter a high turnout among Arabs.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu apologizes to country's Arab minority
entry.summary: He said Netanyahu's prediction that a Palestinian state wouldn't come about on his watch was "very troubling" and questioned Netanyahu's broader commitment to the two-state solution the U.S. and Israel have officially supported for years.

entry.title: Top Obama aide: US can't ignore Netanyahu's comments
entry.summary:
On Monday, Netanyahu apologized to Israel's Arab citizens for another set of remarks that offended members of the community and drew additional U.S. criticism.

Obama's decision to dispatch his chief of staff to speak to J Street, just days after the election, was perceived as another sign that Obama intends to take a tougher tack toward Netanyahu despite his insistence that the U.S.-Israeli relationship is still strong.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu apologizes to country's Arab minority
entry.summary: But President Barack Obama's chief of staff, Denis McDonough, rejected Netanyahu's attempt to distance himself from his comments, telling an Israel advocacy group Monday that the U.S. can't just overlook what Netanyahu said on the eve of his re-election.

entry.title: Netanyahu tells Israel's Arabs he 'regrets' election-day rallying call
entry.summary: Speaking to the group of Israeli Arabs at his official residence in Jerusalem on Monday, Netanyahu said: "I consider myself as prime minister of each one of you, of all Israel's citizens, regardless of religion, race or gender."

entry.title: Netanyahu tells Israel's Arabs he "regrets" election-day rallying call
entry.summary: In a video clip posted on his Facebook page, Netanyahu told representatives of Israel's Arab community: "I know that the things I said a few days ago offended Israel's Arabs. I had no intention for this to happen, I regret this."

entry.title: Israeli PM regrets offending Arab-Israelis during poll
entry.summary: Netanyahu drew accusations of racism in Israel when he warned that "the Arabs are voting in droves," just a few hours before polling stations were to close across the country.

entry.title: Israel?s Netanyahu Apologizes to Country?s Arab Minority
entry.summary: Netanyahu, whose Likud Party won re-election in the vote, met with members of the Arab community at the prime minister's residence in Jerusalem on Monday and apologized.

entry.title: U.S. considers ways to sidestep Netanyahu after he raises doubts he would ever accept Palestinian state
entry.summary: "If the Americans are finding it difficult to understand or accept our clarifications, this is certainly worrying and requires tending to," said Yuval Steinitz, Israel's strategic affairs minister, and a close Netanyahu ally.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu appears poised to build new coalition after securing majority backing
entry.summary:
It became a formality after the new centrist party Kulanu gave its nod to Netanyahu as well, giving him 61 backers out of the 120 in parliament.

Rivlin is scheduled to meet with Netanyahu later this week and officially set the coalition talks into motion.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu appears poised to build coalition
entry.summary: Netanyahu appears poised to set up a coalition with Kulanu and several religious and ultra-Orthodox parties.

entry.title: Netanyahu, Obama rift ratchets up the rhetoric on all sides
entry.summary: Ignoring Mr. Netanyahu's attempt in postelection interviews to walk back his comments, Mr. Obama made clear - as have senior members of his administration in recent days - that he believes Mr. Netanyahu is opposed to the creation of a Palestinian state.

entry.title: Netanyahu allies blame White House criticism on misunderstanding
entry.summary: Obama also took Netanyahu to task for an Internet post on the day of the election in which the prime minister urged right-wing supporters to vote because Arab Israelis were doing so in large numbers.

entry.title: Netanyahu allies blame White House criticism on misunderstanding
entry.summary:
In the United States, where relations with Netanyahu have become a partisan issue after generations in which support for Israel was a point of bipartisan unity, Republican Senator John McCain said Obama should get over his "temper tantrum".

Since winning re-election, Netanyahu has tried to row back, arguing that he was not rejecting Palestinian statehood in principle, but responding to a reality in which the Palestinian Authority has a political pact with the Islamist group Hamas, under which statehood would be unacceptable.

Israel's Strategic Affairs Minister Yuval Steinitz, a close Netanyahu ally, acknowledged the problem but pointed the finger at Washington for failing to understand the prime minister's position.

Netanyahu has long had a difficult relationship with Obama, and made it worse two weeks before the election by addressing the U.S. Congress at the invitation of opposition Republicans to condemn the administration's nuclear negotiations with Iran.

entry.title: Netanyahu's election rhetoric in Israel may help rein in settler movement
entry.summary: Although settlers responded to Netanyahu's call to shore up his Likud Party at the polls, many complain that the prime minister has not allowed enough settlement construction, and intend to exert pressure for more.

entry.title: Israeli President Calls For Healing After Divisive Election
entry.summary: By winning 30 seats in the 120-member parliament, Netanyahu's Likud looks to have a relatively easy time putting together a 61-seat majority along with its nationalist and religious allies.

entry.title: Israeli president calls for healing after divisive election
entry.summary:
Throughout a close election campaign it looked like he would have a crucial role to play after the vote but a resounding victory by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's Likud party has made his considerations mostly moot.

On Sunday, Rivlin began his consultation with all the parties in parliament to hear their recommendations before he officially tasks Netanyahu.

entry.title: Israeli president calls for healing after Binyamin Netanyahu victory
entry.summary: In a last-ditch attempt to spur his supporters to the polls last week, Netanyahu warned that Arab citizens were voting "in droves" and endangering years of rule by his rightwing Likud.

entry.title: Obama rips Netanyahu over Arab voter comments
entry.summary: During their phone call, Obama said he told Netanyahu that "it is going to be hard to find a path where people are seriously believing that negotiations are possible."

entry.title: Obama says it is now 'hard to find a path' on Israeli-Palestinian peace
entry.summary: Ties worsened when Netanyahu accepted a Republican invitation to speak to the U.S. Congress two weeks before the Israeli election to criticize Obama's quest for such a deal.

entry.title: Netanyahu?s comments make it ?hard to find a path? to peace, Obama says
entry.summary:
In an interview with the Huffington Post, Obama also scolded Netanyahu over his remarks about Arab Israelis voting, making clear that the deep rift in relations between Israel and the United States, its most important ally, is not ending anytime soon.

In the interview, conducted on Friday and published on Saturday, Obama described his Thursday phone call with Netanyahu, two days after the Israeli leader was re-elected.

entry.title: Obama takes Netanyahu 'at his word' on Palestinian state
entry.summary:
The White House was particularly annoyed when Netanyahu accepted an invitation from Republican House Speaker John Boehner to address lawmakers earlier this month.

White House chief of staff Denis McDonough is scheduled on Monday to address J Street, an Israeli advocacy group that opposes Netanyahu.

entry.title: Obama takes Netanyahu 'at his word' on Palestinian state
entry.summary:
Obama, who placed a congratulatory telephone call to Netanyahu on Thursday, said he indicated to the prime minister that the U.S. remains committed to a two-state solution as the only way to keep Israel secure.

Obama also criticized Netanyahu for saying as the election neared that Arab voters were heading to the polls "in droves."

entry.title: For liberal Israelis, Netanyahu's win is a reality check
entry.summary: But in retrospect, it seems a tipping point in favor of Netanyahu occurred when artist Yair Garbuz took to the podium and railed against the "amulet kissers" who support Netanyahu.

entry.title: Netanyahu's election victory a reality check for liberal Israelis
entry.summary: "Israel is split -- between left and right, between Bibi and anti-Bibi, between aspirations for normalcy and aspirations for territory," Caspit wrote, using Netanyahu's nickname.

entry.title: For liberal Israelis, Netanyahu's win is a reality check
entry.summary: Netanyahu since has tried to contain the damage from his statements - saying he remains committed to Palestinian statehood if conditions throughout the region improve - and insisting he is not a racist.

entry.title: For liberal Israelis, Netanyahu's victory is a reality check from Israel's hawkish majority
entry.summary: Activists at the headquarters of V-15, an initiative that called to unseat Netanyahu, silently bundled dozens of banners on Thursday, and one activist asked a journalist to leave.

entry.title: For liberal Israelis, Netanyahu's victory is a reality check from Israel's hawkish majority
entry.summary:
But as the results trickled in on Wednesday, they showed Likud with a shocking lead that has all but guaranteed Netanyahu a third consecutive term.

Social media was full of embittered Israelis accusing Netanyahu's supporters of racism, and some vowed to stop donating charity to the underprivileged whom they perceived as being automatic supporters of the right.

entry.title: Netanyahu row casts doubt on Obama pledge to 'have Israel's back'
entry.summary:
As internal discussions proceeded on Friday, the White House appeared in no rush to lower the temperature in the worst U.S.-Israeli crisis in decades, sparked by Netanyahu's campaign declaration that there would be no Palestinian state on his watch.

The White House made clear for a second straight day that it had little faith in Netanyahu's effort to backtrack since winning Tuesday's election and insist he was in favor of a two-state solution, long a cornerstone of U.S. Middle East policy.

There was no sign of any imminent move to turn the administration's heated rhetoric against Netanyahu into a tangible shift in policy.

As a result, some analysts questioned whether Washington was merely posturing to put the Israeli leader on the defensive at a time when an end-of-March deadline looms in U.S.-led nuclear diplomacy with Iran that Netanyahu vehemently opposes.

"The administration is putting everything on the table except security assistance - and this will allow Netanyahu time to walk back his comments more credibly," said Daniel Kurtzer, former U.S. ambassador to Israel.

White House officials have left little doubt that Netanyahu's U.S. ambassador, Ron Dermer, has been largely frozen out by parts of the administration for his role in orchestrating Netanyahu's speech to Congress this month against Obama's Iran diplomacy.

entry.title: Boehner off to Israel; Netanyahu's ties to Obama hit new low
entry.summary: Sen. Marco Rubio, R-Fla., a potential presidential candidate, said in a floor speech Thursday that the rift between Obama and Netanyahu needs to be worked out privately to avoid empowering U.S. and Israeli enemies.

entry.title: Boehner off to Israel; Netanyahu's Ties to Obama Hit New Low
entry.summary: Obama called Netanyahu to congratulate him on his re-election, but also told the Israeli leader that the U.S. is reassessing its approach to Israeli-Palestinian peace in light of his comments about a Palestinian state.

entry.title: Israeli Arabs say they feel a greater sense of exclusion following Netanyahu election win
entry.summary: After initially trailing in opinion polls, Netanyahu's Likud Party did well in traditional strongholds, including working class towns with large numbers of Sephardic Jews of Middle Eastern descent.

entry.title: Israeli Arabs say they feel more excluded after election
entry.summary:
The election, in which Netanyahu eventually secured his fourth term, highlighted the fraught relationship between Israel's Arab citizens and the Jewish state.

In what was seen as an attempt to galvanize his hard-line supporters during Tuesday's election, Netanyahu had warned that "Arab voters are going in droves to the polls," with the help of "left-wing" activists.

Asked by NPR if he would engage in fence-mending, given how his remarks were received, Netanyahu said: "Well, I certainly will make sure that everybody understands that I'm the prime minister of all of Israel's citizens, and I really believe that. It's something that my actions have shown. It's not a question of fence-mending, it's a question of real belief, and it's there. I don't have to fabricate it."

entry.title: Israeli Arabs say they feel a greater sense of exclusion following Netanyahu election win
entry.summary: Netanyahu, defending his record amid widespread criticism of his election-day remarks, told NBC that his government has spent "billions" in Arab towns to upgrade infrastructure and schools.

entry.title: Relations with US strained as Netanyahu seizes power
entry.summary: Copies of ballot papers and campaign posters for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's Likud Party abandoned after the nation's elections on Wednesday.

entry.title: US to 'reassess' options with Israel, Barack Obama tells Benjamin Netanyahu
Israeli leader Netanyahu backtracks from opposition to Palestinian independence
entry.summary: White House spokesman Josh Earnest said Thursday that White House officials were talking to their Israeli counterparts to set up a call between Obama and Netanyahu, possible later in the day.

entry.title: In Netanyahu call, Obama says US reassessing peace approach
entry.summary: But a White House official said Obama also raised Netanyahu's critical comments about Israeli Arabs ahead of the election, which the White House has denounced as a "cynical" effort to mobilize voters.

entry.title: Obama tells Netanyahu U.S. to 'reassess' policy on Israel, Mideast diplomacy
entry.summary: Obama's telephone call to Netanyahu followed a television interview in which the Israeli leader backed away from his pre-election declaration that there would be no Palestinian state on his watch, an about-face apparently aimed at quelling U.S. criticism triggered by his comments.

entry.title: Obama tells Netanyahu U.S. to 'reassess' policy on Israel, Mideast diplomacy
entry.summary:
An official statement put out later in the day said Obama called Netanyahu to congratulate him on his election win and used the opportunity to reaffirm his commitment to a two-state solution, a longtime cornerstone of U.S. policy on the Middle East conflict.

White House spokesman Josh Earnest warned earlier that there would be "consequences" for Israel as the Obama administration monitors the formation of Netanyahu's new ruling coalition.

The White House official said in the phone call Obama "also discussed Prime Minister Netanyahu's comments about Israeli Arabs" but gave no details.

entry.title: Newly re-elected Netanyahu backtracks on Palestinian state opposition
entry.summary:
Netanyahu said in a TV interview Thursday that he remains committed to Palestinian statehood - if conditions in the region improve - and to the two-state vision first spelled out in a landmark 2009 speech at Israel's Bar Ilan University.

"You can't impose peace. And in any case, if you want to get peace, you've got to get the Palestinian leadership to abandon their pact with Hamas and engage in genuine negotiations with Israel for an achievable peace," Netanyahu said.

entry.title: Netanyahu victory likely to deepen split among American Jews over Israel
entry.summary: Netanyahu's disavowal of a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict has been met with alarm in the United States.

entry.title: Netanyahu denies abandoning two-state solution
entry.summary:
Iran, which backs Hamas in the Gaza Strip, was ready to start pouring arms into the West Bank run by the Palestinian Authority, Netanyahu claimed.

The White House on Wednesday had chastised Netanyahu for his remarks, saying such rhetoric "seeks to marginalize Arab-Israeli citizens."

entry.title: Netanyahu backtracks from opposition to Palestinian state
entry.summary: A day before the election Netanyahu told the nrg news website that a Palestinian state would not be established on his watch because of the current climate in the region.

entry.title: Benjamin Netanyahu walks back his opposition to a Palestinian state
entry.summary: Jerusalem: Days after winning Israel's election, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu appears to be backtracking from hard-line statements that ruled out the establishment of a Palestinian state.

entry.title: Benjamin Netanyahu walks back his opposition to a Palestinian state
entry.summary: Now Mr Netanyahu has said in a TV interview that he remains committed to Palestinian statehood - if conditions in the region improve.

entry.title: Analysis: Why Netanyahu? It's more than just nationalism
entry.summary: The reasons for that outcome go beyond the party's nationalist ideology and include Israel's sense of geographic vulnerability, its fragmented politics and a master campaigner in Netanyahu himself.

entry.title: Analysis: Why Netanyahu? It's more than just nationalism
entry.summary: Netanyahu's Likud won 30 seats in the 120-seat parliament, and parties apparently willing to back him won another 37 for a possible majority.

entry.title: Centrist leader vows not to join Israeli government, accuses Netanyahu of racism
entry.summary: Isaac Herzog said his Zionist Union, which finished second in Tuesday's vote, would sit in the opposition as a counterweight to the nationalist right-wing governing coalition that Netanyahu is poised to form.

entry.title: Analysis: Why Netanyahu? It's more than just nationalism
entry.summary:
It's a mystery to many: Benjamin Netanyahu's campaign gained steam when he ruled out the creation of a Palestinian state, and he seems determined to continue settling occupied land with Jews.

The fact that Islamic State militants are menacing the region does not help, and was exploited by Netanyahu during a campaign in which he portrayed the militants in one TV ad as charging toward Jerusalem, with naive Israeli leftists even helpfully pointing the way.

entry.title: Analysis: Why Netanyahu? It's more than just nationalism
Chief Netanyahu rival won't join coalition, claims PM's campaign 'touched on racism'
entry.summary: Herzog also accused Netanyahu of running a campaign based on "lies, fear-mongering, hostility" and said the premier's earlier claim that foreign governments were working to oust him was a "complete lie."

entry.title: Hard-right shift delivers upset election win for Netanyahu
entry.summary:
With nearly all votes counted, Netanyahu's Likud had won 29 or 30 seats in the 120-member Knesset, comfortably defeating the center-left Zionist Union opposition on 24 seats.

The White House scolded Netanyahu for abandoning his commitment to negotiate for a Palestinian state and for what it called "divisive" campaign rhetoric toward Israel's minority Arab voters.

Netanyahu's victory also raises questions about what happens on Iran, with Obama determined to pursue negotiations toward an agreement on Tehran's nuclear program and the Israeli leader determined to foil what he has termed a "very bad deal".

entry.title: Hard-right shift delivers upset election win for Netanyahu
entry.summary: The result was a dramatic and unexpected victory for Netanyahu - the last opinion polls four days before the vote had shown Likud trailing the Zionist Union by four seats.

entry.title: U.S. rebukes Israel's victorious Netanyahu on Mideast policy
entry.summary:
Some Obama aides had privately left little doubt during the Israeli election campaign of their preference for Netanyahu's center-left challenger, Isaac Herzog.

Netanyahu's insistence that there will be no Palestinian state while he holds office, seen as a maneuver to mobilize his right-wing base, angered the Palestinians and drew criticism from the United Nations and European governments.

Speaking to reporters aboard Air Force One, Earnest said the administration would communicate its concern directly to the Israeli government over rhetoric used by Netanyahu's campaign.

Netanyahu charged on election day in Israel that left-wingers were trying to get Arab-Israeli voters out "in droves" to sway the election against him.

Two weeks ago Netanyahu defied Obama with a politically divisive speech to Congress attacking U.S.-led nuclear talks with Iran.

entry.title: Netanyahu sweeps past main challenger in Israeli election
entry.summary: In the final days of campaigning, Netanyahu abandoned a commitment to negotiate a Palestinian state - the basis of more than two decades of Middle East peacemaking - and promised to go on building settlements on occupied land.

entry.title: Netanyahu surges to victory in Israeli vote
entry.summary:
Dore Gold, a confidant and unofficial adviser to Netanyahu, said he was confident the prime minister could repair the relationship with the U.S., Israel's closest and most important ally.

Netanyahu's right-wing Likud Party scored a resounding victory in Israel's election, final results showed Wednesday, a stunning turnaround after a tight race that had put his lengthy rule in jeopardy.

entry.title: Netanyahu surges to victory in Israeli vote
entry.summary: White House spokesman Josh Earnest also said the U.S. would have to rethink the best way to bring about a two-state resolution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict - a cornerstone of U.S. Mideast policy for years - after Netanyahu rejected the idea.

entry.title: US chides Netanyahu?s party after Israeli election win
entry.summary:
In its first public response to Netanyahu's triumph in the election, the spokesman said the White House was "deeply concerned" about divisive language emanating from Netanyahu's Likud Party.

Secretary of State John Kerry spoke to Netanyahu shortly after the election to congratulate him, Earnest said, and Obama was to do the same in the days ahead.

entry.title: AP Analysis: Palestinians see opportunities in Netanyahu win
entry.summary:
Abbas has long argued that Netanyahu was never serious about a partition deal, despite the Israeli leader's assurances to the United States and the European Union.

If Netanyahu keeps expanding settlements in the West Bank and east Jerusalem - already home to close to 600,000 Israelis - such a state may soon be impossible to set up.

entry.title: Palestinians want world pressure on Israel after Netanyahu win
entry.summary:
Netanyahu's surprise victory, after pledging in the final days of the campaign that there would be no Palestinian state as long as he was in power, left Palestinians grim about prospects for a negotiated solution to a decades-old conflict.

Seeking to shore up right-wing votes and saying that Islamist militants would move into any territory relinquished by Israel, Netanyahu also vowed to keep building settlements on occupied land Palestinians seek for a state.

Netanyahu, who in 2009 had endorsed the two-state solution, seemed on course to form a coalition government leaning further to the right than his outgoing cabinet, which had included two centrist parties and engaged in the U.S-brokered peace talks.

In his new coalition, Netanyahu is expected to include his natural allies, religious and far-right parties, as well as one centrist party which campaigned on internal social-economic issues rather than on matters of war and peace.

Though Israeli officials have indicated no imminent change, Gaza-based political analyst Hani Habeeb said Netanyahu may unfreeze the funds, which cover around two-thirds of the Palestinian budget, now that the election is over.

entry.title: Netanyahu owes win to jitters over Iran-Gulf official
entry.summary: Netanyahu won an unexpected election victory on Wednesday after tacking hard to the right in late campaigning, including abandoning a commitment to negotiate a Palestinian state.

entry.title: Netanyahu's Likud Party Wins Israeli Election
entry.summary: The critical party to get on side will be centrist Kulanu, led by former Likud member Moshe Kahlon, who won 10 seats, making him a kingmaker given his ability to side with either Mr Netanyahu or the centre-left opposition.

entry.title: Opposition leader concedes Israel election to Netanyahu
entry.summary: "A few minutes ago I spoke with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and congratulated him on his achievement and wished him luck," Herzog told reporters.

entry.title: Netanyahu?s Likud Wins Israeli Election
entry.summary: The Palestinians, fed up after years of deadlock with Netanyahu, are now likely to press ahead with their attempts to bring war crimes charges against Israel in the International Criminal Court.

entry.title: TOO CLOSE TO CALL Netanyahu, chief opponent both vow to form next gov't

Several smaller centrist and religious parties that have not pledged support for either Netanyahu or Herzog will likely tip the scales to determine who will become prime minister.

In his interview with Channel 10, Netanyahu ruled out a coalition with Herzog and said he would seek an alliance with the ultra-national Jewish Home party, which also opposes Palestinian statehood.

entry.title: Despite a Remarkable Turnaround, Netanyahu's Fate Remains Uncertain
entry.summary: But after days in which Zionist Union appeared poised to defeat Netanyahu's Likud, the exit polls late on Tuesday put the two parties in a dead heat.

entry.title: Netanyahu claims victory in Israel election after hard right shift

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu has slight edge as rivals will compete to form coalition
entry.summary: Netanyahu, who already has a testy relationship with President Barack Obama, took a sharp turn to the right in the final days of the campaign, staking out a series of hard-line positions that will put him at odds with the international community.

entry.title: AP ANALYSIS: Advantage Netanyahu in close race
entry.summary: If Kahlon does go with Netanyahu, it would give the hard-liner a fourth term that, if completed, would make him Israel's longest-serving leader, on par with the nation's founder David Ben Gurion.

entry.title: AP ANALYSIS: Fractured parliament seems likely to leave Netanyahu in job, Israel isolated
entry.summary: Breaking away from Netanyahu's nationalist Likud two years ago after a falling out with the premier, he adopted a vaguely centrist platform and flirted with Isaac Herzog's more moderate Zionist Union.

entry.title: Despite Tie, Netanyahu Secures Shot at 4th Term as Israel PM
entry.summary: Israel's parliament election ended in a deadlock, according to TV exit polls, but Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu seems to hold the advantage ahead of coalition talks.

entry.title: Despite tie, Netanyahu secures shot at 4th term as Israel PM
entry.summary: When Netanyahu called early elections three months ago, Herzog and his Labor Party were seen as politically too weak to mount an effective challenge.

entry.title: Netanyahu Urges Right-Wing Parties To Form Government 'Without Delay'

entry.title: Netanyahu Declares Victory In Israel Elections

entry.title: Netanyahu, on Twitter, says won 'great victory' in Israel's election
entry.summary: "Against all odds: a great victory for Likud, a great victory for the national camp led by Likud, a great victory for the people of Israel," Netanyahu wrote on his official Twitter account.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu declares victory in tight election
Netanyahu vows no Palestinian state
entry.summary:
Zionist Union leader Isaac Herzog conceded defeat and congratulated Netanyahu on winning a third consecutive term.

Netanyahu pledged to establish a new government within weeks and said he had already spoken with right wing and religious party leaders whose support he will need to form a majority coalition.

Netanyahu had put security at the forefront of his campaign, arguing he is the only one capable of protecting Israel from an Iranian nuclear threat and vowing never to allow the Palestinians to establish a capital in east Jerusalem.

"It is clear that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu will form the next government, so we say clearly that we will go to the International Criminal Court in the Hague and we will speed up, pursue and intensify" all diplomatic efforts, chief negotiator Saeb Erakat said.

entry.title: Polls open in Israeli general election
entry.summary: Netanyahu has warned a vote for the Zionist Union could endanger Israel's security and lead to the division of Jerusalem and the establishment of a Palestinian state in the annexed eastern sector.

entry.title: Israelis go to the polls

entry.title: As Israelis Vote, Netanyahu Rules out Palestinian State
entry.summary: Both Netanyahu and Herzog will now compete for a chance to form a coalition that commands a majority in the 120-seat parliament, a daunting task in Israel's fractured political landscape.

entry.title: As Israelis vote, Netanyahu rules out Palestinian state
entry.summary: His chief rival, Isaac Herzog of the Zionist Union, said he would make "every effort" to form a government, and an upstart centrist party led by a former Netanyahu ally-turned-rival was set to be the kingmaker.

entry.title: No Palestinian state while I am PM, says faltering Netanyahu
entry.summary:
In an election eve about-face, Benjamin Netanyahu has vowed there will never be a Palestinian state as long as he is prime minister, contradicting a previous commitment in a bid to woo wavering right-wing voters back to his Likud Party.

In 2009 - the election in which Mr Netanyahu took the prime ministership for a second time - the centrist Kadima party won the most seats but was unable to form a coalition and in the end, Mr Netanyahu took power.

entry.title: No Palestinian state while I am PM, says faltering Netanyahu

entry.title: Netanyahu votes as polls open in Israeli election
entry.summary: "I think that anyone who moves to establish a Palestinian state and evacuate territory gives territory away to radical Islamist attacks against Israel," Netanyahu said.

entry.title: Netanyahu promises no Palestinian state if reelected

entry.title: Netanyahu says no Palestinian state if reelected

entry.title: Netanyahu promises no Palestinian state if re-elected
entry.summary: When asked if that means a Palestinian state will not be established if he is elected, Netanyahu said "indeed."

entry.title: Benjamin Netanyahu promises no Palestinian state if he is re-elected

entry.title: Benjamin Netanyahu plays the hardline settlement expansion card to capture right-wing voters
entry.summary:
But it is not just voters who care about economic issues who have turned against the ruling Likud Party, it is also security experts who have despaired at Mr Netanyahu's insistence on focusing on Iran above all else.

"You and you alone turned the United States from an ally into an enemy," Shabtai Shavit, a former chief of the Mossad spy agency, said of Mr Netanyahu's actions, including his widely-condemned Iran speech to the US Congress earlier this month.

entry.title: Israel election: Benjamin Netanyahu may be on his way out
entry.summary:
Tel Aviv: In 1996, a canny and polished politician named Benjamin Netanyahu stormed onto the electoral scene and became Israel's youngest prime minister.

For Mr Netanyahu's main competition, a centre-left party known as the Zionist Union, the message was simple: It's time for the Prime Minister to go.

In 2013, Ms Livni's Kadima party bested Mr Netanyahu's by a single seat, but she was unable to muster enough support for a workable coalition.

entry.title: Israel election: Benjamin Netanyahu may be on his way out
entry.summary:
Soaring housing costs, in particular, became a prominent issue in this campaign, but Mr Netanyahu infuriated many voters by appearing to brush off their concerns in favour of a relentless focus on the Iranian nuclear threat.

Voters turning their backs on Mr Netanyahu and the Likud are likelier to migrate to centrist or right-leaning parties rather than the Zionist Union.

entry.title: Prevent 'left-wing' government, Netanyahu tells campaign rally
entry.summary: "Our rivals are investing a huge effort to harm me and the Likud, to open a gap between my party, the Likud, and (our rivals), and if we don't close this gap, there is a real danger that a left-wing government will rise to power," Netanyahu said.

entry.title: Prevent 'left-wing' government, Netanyahu tells campaign rally
entry.summary:
Speaking to a rally of thousands of supporters of Israel's right-wing parties from behind a bulletproof screen at Tel Aviv's main square, Netanyahu warned that the right-wing government he leads could be voted out of office.

Even if Likud is outnumbered, Netanyahu is counting on a larger right-wing bloc to support his bid for another term and Kahlon, with around 10 seats in the polls, could tilt things in his favor.

After realizing he was trailing his opponents in the polls, Netanyahu launched a media blitz to counter the apparent rising tide of support for the Zionist Union, his main opponent.

entry.title: Netanyahu legacy on the line in Israeli vote
entry.summary: Iran and the international community seem headed toward a nuclear deal that Netanyahu abhors, and a resolution to the Palestinian issue seems as distant as ever.

entry.title: Netanyahu legacy on the line in Israeli vote
entry.summary: Despite Netanyahu's speech to Congress, his efforts to halt the Iranian nuclear program which he describes as the mission of his lifetime appear to be stumbling as the U.S. seems to move toward a deal with the Islamic Republic.

entry.title: In close election, Netanyahu's legacy on the line
entry.summary: But if Likud stumbles and finds itself in the opposition - a real possibility, according to recent polls - the Netanyahu era could end with a resounding thud, concluding a career that many would say brought few major accomplishments beyond longevity.

entry.title: Netanyahu's legacy on as Israelis prepare to vote Tuesday
entry.summary:
But on a basic level, the campaign is simply a referendum on Netanyahu, a polarizing character who is adored as "King Bibi" by his supporters and reviled by his detractors.

But Hendel said he believes that if Netanyahu leaves office, he would not be satisfied with the outcome of the two most pressing issues: Iran's nuclear program and the lack of resolution with the Palestinians.

entry.title: Flagging as election looms, Netanyahu ramps up rhetoric
entry.summary:
"There is a huge international effort, with major money, that is partnering up with leftist organizations here and also with media figures in order to bring down the Likud government that I head," Netanyahu told Channel 2 television on Saturday.

Herzog, who was also interviewed by Channel 2, shot back at Netanyahu: "The international community knows you are weak."

At a speech earlier, Herzog accused Likud and Netanyahu of responding with "spin" to a public "fed up" with them.

Rancour has also seeped into Likud, where some officials privately blame Netanyahu for a scattergun campaign and blowback from his March 3 speech to the U.S. Congress against the Obama administration's Iran strategy.

"We're closing ranks now, but if Tuesday turns out badly for us, there will be a reckoning," one senior Likud delegate said, hinting Netanyahu could be ousted as party head.

entry.title: Israel election: Netanyahu shifts tactics as Likud appears to slip

But even on the security front Mr Netanyahu has found himself challenged, with his critics accusing him of fraying Israel's ties with its most crucially, the United States, over the Iranian issue.

entry.title: Israel election: Netanyahu shifts tactics as Likud appears to slip

entry.title: AP Analysis: Speech fallout could determine Netanyahu's fate

The event was engineered by the Republican House speaker, John Boehner, and Netanyahu's ambassador to Washington, U.S.-born Ron Dermer, who once worked as a Republican operative.

entry.title: After speech, White House could determine Netanyahu's fate
entry.summary:
Which way it goes for Netanyahu may hinge on whether Israel is in some perceptible way punished by the White House for its leader's extraordinary offensive against a U.S. president.

At home and abroad, Netanyahu is seen by many as a leading obstacle to peace with the Palestinians and perhaps the Arab world.

For this and other reasons, Netanyahu has found himself at increasingly toxic loggerheads with the country's elites - from the security establishment to academics, journalists, cultural figures and much of the business world.

Polls show Netanyahu's Likud party slightly trailing the Zionist Union, which is the main grouping of the center-left opposition.

He presented Israel as peace-loving and progressive and stressed its deep bonds to the U.S. He even produced Nobel laureate and Holocaust survivor Elie Wiesel, who waved as Netanyahu intoned "Never Again."

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu draws rebuke from Obama over Iran speech to Congress
entry.summary: Netanyahu made his case against Obama's Iran diplomacy in a speech to Congress that aligned himself with the president's Republican foes.

entry.title: Barack Obama, Benjamin Netanyahu relationship frankly, transparently poisonous
entry.summary:
US President Barack Obama has not hidden his unhappiness with Israel's PM Benjamin Netanyahu.

A source identified by CNN only as an angry senior White House official said Netanyahu had proposed "literally not one new idea; not one single concrete alternative; all rhetoric, no action".

Obama's chief diplomat, John Kerry, was labelled "obsessive" and "messianic" by Netanyahu's defence minister, Moshe Yaalon, for his pursuit of peace between Israel and the Palestinians.

entry.title: Benjamin Netanyahu gives controversial speech to US congress
entry.summary:
Mr Netanyahu was welcomed to the joint session of Congress with thunderous applause from Republican members, while over 50 Democrats - including six Jewish representatives - boycotted the address.

Standing at the speaker's lectern from which Mr Obama gives his State of Union address, Mr Netanyahu depicted Mr Obama as naive, saying that in attempting to negotiate a settlement with Iran he was gambling the security of the world.

entry.title: No precedent for Netanyahu's contentious speech to Congress
entry.summary: In a speech that stirred political intrigue in two countries, Netanyahu told Congress that negotiations underway between Iran and the U.S. would "all but guarantee" that Tehran will get nuclear weapons, a step that the world must avoid at all costs.

entry.title: Israel's Netanyahu warns U.S. of 'nuclear nightmare'
entry.summary: In an appearance boycotted by dozens of Obama's fellow Democrats, Netanyahu said Iran's leadership was "as radical as ever" and could not be trusted and the deal being worked out by the United States and other world powers would not block Iran's way to a bomb "but paves its way to a bomb."

entry.title: Watch live: Benjamin Netanyahu's address to US Congress over Iran nuclear deal
entry.summary: Netanyahu insists he is privy to emerging details of a deal and is expected to lay out specific concerns in Tuesday's speech to a joint meeting of Congress.

entry.title: Kerry working on Iran nuke deal, Netanyahu to criticize it
entry.summary: The officials said earlier they expected the talks would resume and likely continue through Netanyahu's address to Congress, delivered in the late afternoon local time in Montreux.

entry.title: Netanyahu to use Congress' bully pulpit to assail Iran talks
entry.summary:
Two weeks ahead of voting in his own re-election back home, Netanyahu took the podium of the U.S. House where presidents often make major addresses, contending that any nuclear deal with Iran could threaten his nation's survival.

House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., did little to hide her unease and later issued a blistering statement criticizing what she called Netanyahu's condescension.

According to Netanyahu, the deal on the table offers two major concessions: Iran would be left with a vast nuclear infrastructure and restrictions on Iran's nuclear program would be lifted in about a decade.

entry.title: Netanyahu to use Congress' bully pulpit to assail Iran talks
Netanyahu to use Congress platform to assail Iran talks
entry.summary:
Republicans loudly cheered Netanyahu in the packed chamber, repeatedly standing.

Said Isaac Herzog, who is running against Netanyahu: "The painful truth is that after the applause, Netanyahu remains alone and Israel remains isolated and the negotiations with Iran will continue without Israel. It won't change the (U.S.)

entry.title: US-Israel ties sorely tested as Netanyahu's Congress speech draws near
entry.summary:
Later Mr Obama told Reuters that while he had no personal issue with Mr Netanyahu, the US had its own policymaking process, adding that Mr Netanyahu's warnings over preliminary agreements with Iran had proved unfounded.

During his speech to AIPAC, Mr Netanyahu said that while US leaders were concerned for American safety, Israel's were forced to fear for their nation's very survival, and this perspective had lead to disagreements between the two nations in the past.

Though Mr Obama agreed - at least to the point of saying that the discord between the leaders is not "permanently destructive" - observers agree that Mr Netanyahu's speech has caused real damage to the relationship between the nations.

Last week Dr Rice told an interviewer: "What has happened over the last several weeks - by virtue of the invitation that was issued by the Speaker and the acceptance of it by Prime Minister Netanyahu two weeks in advance of his election - is that on both sides, there has now been injected a degree of partisanship.

entry.title: Foreign talks to Congress often a yawn, but not Netanyahu's
entry.summary: In a preview of his speech to Congress, Netanyahu told a pro-Israel conference in Washington Monday that he has a moral duty to warn that President Barack Obama's nuclear negotiations with Iran may imperil Israel.

entry.title: Foreign talks to Congress often a yawn, but not Netanyahu's
Foreign talks to Congress often a yawn, but not Netanyahu's
entry.summary: WASHINGTON (AP) - Given anywhere else, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's speech Tuesday wouldn't cause such a fuss.

entry.title: Benjamin Netanyahu tiptoes through diplomatic minefield in Washington ahead of speech
entry.summary:
Mr Netanyahu said that while American leaders worry about their nation's security, Israel's feared for their nation's survival, and this differing point of view had lead to disagreements between the two nations in the past.

The speech is being given just a fortnight before the Israeli elections, leading many to speculate that Mr Netanyahu is risking his nation's most crucial alliance for domestic political gain.

Mr Obama will not meet with Mr Netanyahu, and around 30 Democratic representatives from Congress have said they will not attend the speech, including the Vice President, Joe Biden, who also serves as President Pro Tem, or president of the Senate.

entry.title: Netanyahu says Iran deal could threaten Israel's existence
entry.summary: Mr Netanyahu is expected to press US politicians to block a deal with Iran that he contends would endanger Israel's existence but which Mr Obama's aides believe could be a signature foreign policy achievement for the president.

entry.title: Benjamin Netanyahu tries to derail Barack Obama's hopes for Iran nuclear deal
entry.summary: "The purpose of my address to Congress tomorrow is to speak up about a potential deal with Iran that could threaten the survival of Israel," Mr Netanyahu said.

entry.title: On US visit, Netanyahu warns an Iran deal could threaten Israel's existence
entry.summary: Washington: Having provoked a diplomatic row with the Obama administration, Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu told an audience of thousands in Washington, DC, that the relationship between the two nations would grow and strengthen.

entry.title: Netanyahu: Iran nuclear deal threatens Israel's security
entry.summary: Netanyahu tried to paper over his personal differences with Obama, insisting he was not in Washington to "disrespect" the president and saying any reports of the demise of U.S.-Israel ties were "not only premature, they're just wrong."

entry.title: Netanyahu says U.S.-Israel relationship 'stronger than ever'
entry.summary:
Neither gave any ground ahead of Netanyahu's speech to Congress on Tuesday when he plans to detail his objections to ongoing talks between Iran and world powers that he says will inevitably allow Tehran to become a nuclear-armed state.

Obama also sought to lower the temperature by describing Netanyahu's planned speech to Congress as a distraction that would not be "permanently destructive" to U.S.-Israeli ties and by saying the rift was not personal.

The invitation to Netanyahu was orchestrated by Republican congressional leaders with the Israeli ambassador without advance word to the White House, a breach of protocol that infuriated the Obama administration and the president's fellow Democrats.

entry.title: Netanyahu arrives in U.S., signs of easing of tensions over Iran speech
entry.summary: Last week, Obama's national security adviser, Susan Rice, said the partisanship caused by Netanyahu's looming address was "destructive to the fabric of U.S.-Israeli ties".

entry.title: Rhetoric eases but tensions remain as Netanyahu flies in to US
entry.summary: The United States and Israel showed signs of seeking to defuse tensions on Sunday ahead of a speech in Washington by Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu when he will warn against a possible nuclear deal with Iran.

entry.title: John Kerry says Netanyahu speech to Congress is becoming a 'political football'
entry.summary: Netanyahu is expected to use his speech to urge Congress to approve new sanctions against Iran despite Obama's pledge to veto such legislation because it would jeopardize nuclear talks.

entry.title: Netanyahu in US, signs of easing of tensions over Iran speech
entry.summary:
A senior Israeli official told reporters on Netanyahu's flight that Congress could be "the last brake" for stopping a nuclear deal with Iran.

Saying it was Israel's impression that members of Congress"do not necessarily know the details of the deal coming together, which we do not see as a good deal," the official said Netanyahu in his speech would give a detailed explanation of his objections to an Iran deal.

entry.title: Kerry trying to calm U.S., Israel relations as Netanyahu speech approaches
entry.summary: Kerry said in an interview broadcast before he arrived in Switzerland for talks with Iran's foreign minister that Netanyahu was welcome to speak in the U.S. and that the administration did not want the event "turned into some great political football."

entry.title: In Benjamin Netanyahu's coming speech to Congress, a message for Israel
entry.summary:
Kerry said he speaks regularly to Netanyahu, including a phone call Saturday, and he said Israel is safer today because of the 2013 interim agreement with Tehran that saw Iran freeze or scale back most of its nuclear development.

"I taught Bibi how to reach the target," said retired Gen. Amiram Levine, using Netanyahu's nickname.

In departing remarks Sunday, Netanyahu referred to the upcoming Jewish holiday of Purim, which commemorates the biblical Esther acting as envoy to a powerful king on behalf of the Jews.

Feinstein said Sunday that she would attend the talk, but that it was "arrogant" for Netanyahu to assert that he speaks for all Jews.

entry.title: Netanyahu flies to U.S.; signs of some easing of tensions over Iran speech seen
entry.summary: Policy differences over the negotiations with Iran remained firm, however, as Netanyahu set off for the United States to deliver the speech, which has imperiled ties between the two allies.

entry.title: Netanyahu flies to U.S. as planned Iran speech threatens to fray ties
entry.summary: Speaking in Tehran on Saturday, Iranian Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif accused Netanyahu of trying to undermine the nuclear talks in order to distract from the Palestinians' unresolved bid for an independent state.

entry.title: News24.com | White House tries to counter Netanyahu visit
entry.summary: Biden will be visiting Uruguay and Guatemala on a trip that was announced after Netanyahu's speech was scheduled, while the State Department announced abruptly this week that Kerry will be traveling to as-yet-determined destinations for the duration of the AIPAC conference.

entry.title: Unwelcome mat: White House tries to counter Netanyahu visit
